questions.Question: Of the total volume of the earth, which layer forms the major part ?
questions.solution: Core forms the major part of the total volume of earth. The innermost layer, forming the metallic centre of the Earth. Core of the Earth is like a dense magnetic ball of minerals (Iron & Nickel). Hence, it is also called NIFE (NI – Nickel & Fe – Ferrous Magnesium i.e Iron). Temperature increases at the rate of 1 degree Celsius for every 32 meters of depth.

questions.Question: On which date is India likely to experience the shortest day?
questions.solution: We know India lies in the Northern Hemisphere as it lies above the Equator. The shortest day in the Northern Hemisphere is on December 22nd, when the Sun is directly overhead the tropic of Capricorn.

questions.Question: When does the Sun shine vertically on the Equator?
questions.solution: When the sun shines vertically over the equator then it is known as equinox. Twice, on the March equinox (typically around March 21) and on the September equinox (typically around September 22).

questions.Question: When it is nine o'clock in London, it will be the same time in ________
questions.solution: There is no time difference between London, UK and Ghana. When it is nine o'clock in London, it will be the same time in Ghana.

questions.Question: Which of the following Isohels are the isopleths of
questions.solution: Isohels are the imaginary lines connecting places where Sunlight falls for same duration & isopleths are the imaginery lines connecting places with equal incidence of meteorological phenomenon. So, Sunlight's observed duration would remain equal at places where the Sun can be observe equally.

questions.Question: The imaginary lines joining places of same height at equal intervals are
questions.solution: Imaginary lines joining places of same height at equal intervals are contour lines. These are the closed loops used to showcase the similar hight point.

questions.Question: Which of the following layers of the earth is believed to have the heaviest mineral materials of highest density ?
questions.solution: The layers of the earth that is believed to have the heaviest mineral materials of highest density is Central core. Earth’s core is the very hot, very dense center of our planet. The ball-shaped core lies beneath the cool, brittle crust and the mostly-solid mantle.

questions.Question: What is the study of Moon called?
questions.solution: In Greek, our moon is named "Selene," as is the moon goddess of ancient Greek mythology. The English word "selenology," or the study of the moon's geology, derives from it.

questions.Question: Magma that reaches earth's surface and then solidifies is called
questions.solution: Magma that reaches the earth's surface and then solidifies is known as the lava.

questions.Question: What is the term used for the day on 23 September when day and night are equal throughout the world?
questions.solution: Equinoxes occurs twice in a year. The day and night on this day are equal through out the globe as the Sun is exactly above the equator on this day. This phenomenon occuring on 21 March is Spring equinox and other occuring on 23 September is Autumnal Equinox as the Sun is heading towards Tropic of Capricorn.

questions.Question: When it is noon along 82° 30' longitude, along what degree of longitude it will be 6.30 a.m.?
questions.solution: When it is noon along 82° 30' longitude, along 0° E or W degree of longitude it will be 6.30 a.m. The Earth has been divided into 24 time zones of one hour each. Each of these zones covers 15 degrees of longitude.

questions.Question: The approximate circumference of the Earth is
questions.solution: The approximate circumference of the Earth is 40,000 km. The circumference of the Earth in kilometers is 40,075 km, and the circumference of the Earth in miles is 24,901.

questions.Question: For a time difference of two hours, the longitudinal distance will be equal to ________.
questions.solution: One hour of time difference corresponds to 15° of longitude (360°/24 hours = 15°/hour). Therefore, For a time difference of two hours, he longitudinal distance will be equal to 30°.

questions.Question: When it is 12 noon at Greenwich, what is the time at New York (74° W) ?
questions.solution: Greenwich is 4 hours ahead of New York, NY, USA. Greenwich mean time (GMT) = 12 noon every 1° is equal to 4 minutes. therefore, 74° = 74×4 = 296minutes. Therefore, When it is 12 noon at Greenwich, the time at New York (74° W) is 7.04 a.m.

questions.Question: What is the difference between the Local time and Greenwich time one degree longitude?
questions.solution: The time difference between each longitude (each degree) is 4 minutes. So if it is 12 noon at Greenwich (0 degree), it would be 12:04 pm at 1 degree meridian and so on.

questions.Question: The distance between the earth and the sun is smallest in the month of ________
questions.solution: In January Earth makes its closest approach to the Sun for the year.

questions.Question: The heavier silicates named 'Sima' or silica + magnesium are most abundant in the ________
questions.solution: The heavier silicates named as Sima or silica magnesium are most abundant in the Ocean floors.

questions.Question: The process of water getting evaporated from the surface of leaves is known as
questions.solution: The process of water getting evaporated from the surface of leaves is known as Transpiration.

questions.Question: The shortest day in Australia will be on ________
questions.solution: On the 21st of June, 2021 just before 5 p.m. AEST, Australians will bid farewell to the shortest day for the year.

questions.Question: When the Earth is at the maximum distance from the Sun, it is called
questions.solution: The furthest point is called aphelion. The aphelion is the point in the orbit of an object where it is farthest from the Sun. The word aphelion derives from the Greek words, apo meaning away, off, apart and Helios.

questions.Question: In how much time, Earth rotates once on its axis?
questions.solution: Earth rotates once in about 24 hours with respect to the Sun, but once every 23 hours, 56 minutes, and 4.9 seconds with respect to other, distant, stars.

questions.Question: The Earth is tilted on its axis
questions.solution: The axis of rotation of the Earth is tilted at an angle of 23.5 degrees away from vertical, perpendicular to the plane of our planet's orbit around the sun.

questions.Question: The earth's annual circuit round the sun covers a distance of ________
questions.solution: The earth's annual circuit round the Sun covers a distance of 966 million km.

questions.Question: The mean radius of the earth is approximately ________
questions.solution: The mean radius of the earth is approximately 3200 km.

questions.Question: Which planet in our solar system is nearly as big as the Earth?
questions.solution: Venus is nearly as big as the Earth. As it is very similar to Earth in terms of size, average density, mass & surface gravity. It is also known as Earth's twin.

questions.Question: The amount of insolation received at a place on the surface of the earth depends on ________
questions.solution: The amount of insolation received at a place on the surface of the earth depends on its latitude and its climate.

questions.Question: What are the imaginary lines encircling the Earth horizontally called?
questions.solution: Latitude is an imaginary line around the Earth parallel to the Equator. It is the angular distance of a point on Earth's surface from Equator.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is present in the largest amount in terms of percent by mass in the earth's crust?
questions.solution: Oxygen is by far the most abundant element in the earth's crust. Scientists estimate oxygen comprises nearly half of the mass of the crust. It also accounts for 21 percent of Earth's atmosphere.

questions.Question: In the earliest days when life originated on earth, the atmosphere contained ________
questions.solution: In the earliest days when life originated on earth, the atmosphere contained Oxygen bound to carbon.

questions.Question: Summer Solstice in the Southern Hemisphere occurs on ________
questions.solution: Summer Solstice in the Southern Hemisphere occurs on 21st December.

questions.Question: Which of the following celestial body contains Helium-4 in abundance?
questions.solution: Celestial body Earth contains Helium-4 in abundance. Its abundance is similar to this figure in the Sun and in Jupiter. This is due to the very high nuclear binding energy (per nucleon) of helium-4 with respect to the next three elements after helium.

questions.Question: In the context of 'time' GMT means
questions.solution: GMT is Greenwich Mean Time. It is the local time at zero degrees longitude in Greenwich, England and is used as the world reference for times at different longitudes around the globe.

questions.Question: Which of the following pairs of metals are supposed to constitute the internal core of the earth?
questions.solution: The outer core is believed to be made up of iron nickel is because of the theory of paleomagnetism. The change in the magnetic poles all through different geological eras.

questions.Question: On which day, Earth is closest to the Sun?
questions.solution: Due to elliptical path, distance of Earth from Sun keeps changing. It is nearest to Sun on 3rd January known as Perihelion.

questions.Question: Marble is the metamorphosed form of
questions.solution: Marble is a metamorphic rock formed when limestone is exposed to high temperatures and pressures. Marble forms under such conditions because the calcite forming the limestone recrystallises forming a denser rock consisting of roughly equigranular calcite crystals.

questions.Question: Which of the following line represents the line which connects the places of equal rain?
questions.solution: An isohyet is a line on a map which connects points that have the same amounts of precipitation in a given period or for a particular storm.

questions.Question: The light of Sun takes how much time to reach to Earth
questions.solution: Sunlight travels at the speed of light. Photons emitted from the surface of the Sun need to travel across the vacuum of space to reach our eyes. The short answer is that it takes sunlight an average of 8 minutes and 20 seconds to travel from the Sun to the Earth.

questions.Question: Who proposed Continental drift theory?
questions.solution: Continetal Drift theory was proposed by Alfred wegner in 1912. It stated that continents have changedtheir position and initially there was only one big continent named Pangea. Although he was unable to explain the force behind the drifting of continents.

questions.Question: The region which is resistant to the transformation of macro structure, is called?
questions.solution: Shield is the region of stable landmass occupied by resistant rocks of igneous origin, showing resistant to geomorphic processes e.g. Canadian Shield.

questions.Question: What percentage of insolation is received by the earth's surface?
questions.solution: Roughly, 0.47 percent of insolation reaches the Earth's surface. The rest is either reflected and scattered back to space through its interaction with clouds, water vapour, dust and pollen, known collectively as aerosols or it is absorbed by clouds and gaseous elements and hence heats the atmosphere.

questions.Question: The Tropic of Cancer does not pass through ________
questions.solution: Apart from Oman, the Tropic of Cancer passes through the Bahamas, Mexico, Mauritania, Mali, Western Sahara, Algeria, Niger, Libya, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, India, China, UAE, Bangladesh, Burma and Taiwan. It passes through the United States in the Hawaiian region. It does not pass through Yemen.

questions.Question: The mapping of which of the following is most difficult ?
questions.solution: The Earth's interior is composed of four layers, three solid and one liquid not magma but molten metal, nearly as hot as the surface of the sun. The mapping of interior of the Earth of the following is most difficult.

questions.Question: Which of the following phenomenon gives an evidence for the spherical shape of the earth?
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Isobar lines show
questions.solution: A line drawn on a weather map connecting points of equal pressure is called an isobar. Isobars are generated from mean sea level pressure reports and are given in millibars.

questions.Question: Evidence suggests that life on Earth has existed for about ________.
questions.solution: Evidence suggests that life on Earth has existed for about 3.5 billion years. The earliest known fossils on Earth date from 3.5 billion years ago and there is evidence that biological activity took place even earlier - just at the end of the period of late heavy bombardment.

questions.Question: The earth is at the largest distance from the sun (Apehelion) on ________
questions.solution: At about 11 a.m. EDT (1500 GMT) on the Fourth of July, the Earth will reach that point in its orbit where it is farthest from the sun called aphelion, this location in Earth's orbit puts the planet about 94.5 million miles (152 million kilometers) from the sun.

questions.Question: The seasonal contrasts are maximum in ________
questions.solution: Seasonal contrast are maximum in mid latitude.

questions.Question: Geostationary orbit is at a height of ________
questions.solution: The geostationary orbit of the earth is at a distance of about 36000 km from the earth's surface.

questions.Question: A radio broadcast from Delhi on Monday at 7.30 p.m. is heard at New York on ________
questions.solution: A radio broadcast from Delhi on Monday at 7.30 p.m. is heard at New York on the same day at 7:30 a.m..

questions.Question: The position of the sun is annually twice overhead at Singapore because of the ________
questions.optionC: Elliptical path of the earth's orbit
questions.optionD: Parallelism of inclined axis of the earth
questions.solution: The position of the sun is annually twice overhead at Singapore because of the parallelism of inclined axis of the earth.

questions.Question: The desert regions of the world occupy about ________ part of the land surface of the earth.
questions.solution: The desert regions of the world occupy about 1/3part of the land surface of the earth.

questions.Question: Which one of the following elements is most abundant in the earth's crust?
questions.solution: Oxygen is the most abundant element in the Earth's crust. Oxygen makes up 467,100 ppm (parts per million) of the Earth's crust, or 46.6%.

questions.Question: The word used to describe the shape of earth is ________
questions.solution: Oblate Spheroid is a term that has been used to describe the shape of the Earth. The Earth is not a sphere.

questions.Question: Insolation heats up the land masses more quickly than the water bodies because ________
questions.optionC: Water needs more energy to get warm
questions.optionD: Rocks are bad conductors of heat
questions.solution: This is due to the fact that most land surfaces are darker than water which of course means more absorption of solar radiation and heat. Since land absorbs more solar radiation the land surface retains more heat as do the vegetation for energy. Thus, land surfaces warm more quickly than water.

questions.Question: The sun reaches its maximum angular distance from the equator at the ________
questions.solution: Since the ecliptic is tilted 23.5 degrees with respect to the celestial equator, the Sun's maximum angular distance from the celestial equator is 23.5 degrees. This happens at the solstices.

questions.Question: If news is broadcast from London at 10:30 AM, at what time it will be heard at Baghdad (45°E)?
questions.solution: Time at London (0° longitude) is 10:30 am. Baghdad is at 45°E.Difference in longitudes = 45°For every 1° longitude, there is a difference of 4 minutesFor 45° longitude there will be a difference of = (45*4)minutes= 180 minutes or 3 hoursAs Baghdad is towards the east of London, it'll be ahead of time at Londontime at Baghdad = (10:30am + 3 hours)= 1:30pm

questions.Question: If the earth's direction of rotation is reversed, what would be the IST when it is noon at the International Date Line?
questions.solution: India is a large country spanning over 30° of longitude. It is unusual in having a single time zone all over the country, 5½ hours fast. If the direction of rotation of earth is reversed then Indian Standard Time will be – 5½ hr. When it is noon the time is 12:00; that will be 6:30 A.M. in place of 17:30 P.M. or 5:30 P.M.

questions.Question: Sandstone is metamorphosed to
questions.solution: Sandstone can change into quartzite by becoming a metamorphic rock. Sandstone is a sedimentary rock, a type of rock that is made through solidification of sediment layers. In order for sandstone to become quartzite, this rock needs to experience heat and pressure. Most sandstone that has become quartzite was found near compression zones of plate tectonics.

questions.Question: Heat received by earth from the Sun is known as ________
questions.solution: The heat is derived from solar energy, normally called solar radiation. Insolation is the solar radiation that reaches the earth's surface.

questions.Question: The boundary between Earth's Crust and Mantle is ________.
questions.solution: The boundary between the Earth's Crust and Mantle is referred to as Mohorovicic or simply Moho discontinuity. It lies 35 Km below continents & 7 Km beneath the ocean crust.

questions.Question: What is the meaning of "Midnight Sun"?
questions.optionD: Shining of Sun in Arctic and Antarctica circle
questions.solution: The midnight sun is a natural phenomenon that occurs in the summer months in places north of the Arctic Circle or south of the Antarctic Circle, when the Sun remains visible at the local midnight.

questions.Question: What is the interval between a high tide and low tide at a given place?
questions.solution: The difference between high tide & low tide at a given place is about 12 hrs. 26 min. Neap tides occur when the sun, earth and moon form a right angle and the gravitational pull of the sun counteracts the pull of the moon.

questions.Question: During Lunar eclipse, which of the following is at the centre?
questions.solution: Lunar eclipse takes place when Moon passes through the shadow of Earth i.e. Earth comes between Sun and Moon. Apartial eclipse occurs if only a part of Moon passes through the shadow.

questions.Question: The upper part of the mantle upon which the crust of the Earth floats is called ________
questions.solution: The upper part of the mantle upon which the crust of the Earth floats is called Asthenosphere. The layer below the rigid lithosphere is a zone of asphalt-like consistancy called the Asthenosphere.

questions.Question: After Sun, which is the closest star to the Earth?
questions.solution: Proxima Centauri is the nearest star to the solar system. Proxima Centauri is about 4.22 light-years from Earth and is the closest star other than the sun.

questions.Question: Low tides are
questions.solution: Low tides are 20% lower than normal tides. Low tides occur in locations at 90 degree angles to the moon. Low tides are weak.

questions.Question: When would you record the maximum angle of incidence of the sun's rays at the north pole?
questions.optionC: When the sun's rays fall vertically on the Tropic of Cancer
questions.optionD: When the sun's rays fall vertically on the Tropic of Capricorn
questions.solution: When the sun's rays fall vertically on the Tropic of Cancer we can record the maximum angle of incidence of the sun's rays at the north pole.

questions.Question: How many kilometers are represented by 1° of latitude?
questions.solution: Around 111 kilometres( approximately ). It varies from 110.56 kms at the equator to 111.69 at the poles due to the ellipsoid shape of the earth.

questions.Question: What is the position of the Earth when it is at the greatest distance from the Sun?
questions.solution: Earth is farther from the sun today (July 6) than at any other time of the year. On 4th July, Earth is farthest from Sun and this phenomenon is called Aphelion. This happens because Earth orbits round the Sun elliptically.

questions.Question: The planet which has the highest surface temperature is
questions.solution: The greenhouse effect on Venus causes the temperatures at its surface to reach 864 degrees Fahrenheit (462 degrees Celsius), making Venus the hottest planet in the entire Solar System.

questions.Question: The alignment of the lines of beginning and end is expressed by
questions.solution: The alignment of the lines of beginning and end is expressed by feasibility. A feasibility report is a document that assesses potential solutions to the business problem or opportunity, and determines which of these are viable for further analysis.

questions.Question: If a place is located at 20°N, 80°E in which of the following continents does it lie?
questions.solution: If a place is located at 20°N, 80°E it lies in Asia continent. The 20th parallel north is a circle of latitude that is 20 degrees north of the Earth's equatorial plane. It crosses Africa, Asia, the Indian Ocean, the Pacific Ocean, North America, the Caribbean and the Atlantic Ocean.

questions.Question: The sunlight is available 24 hours on the longest day at which of the following latitudes of the Earth?
questions.solution: The sunlight is available 24 hours on the longest day at 66.5°.

questions.Question: The tide at its maximum height is known as ________
questions.solution: The tide at its maximum height is known as Spring tide. A spring tide popularly known as a "King Tide" refers to the 'springing forth' of the tide during new and full moon.

questions.Question: Which of the following is the International Date line?
questions.solution: 180° longitude is the International Date line.

questions.Question: Which among the following statments is true regarding International Date Line?
questions.optionD: It is a curved line beyond Earth
questions.solution: The International Date Line (IDL) is an imaginary line of longitude on the Earth's surface located at about 180° degrees east (or west) of the Greenwich Meridian.

questions.Question: Which star is nearest to the Earth?
questions.solution: Sun which is also a star is the nearest star to Earth. Besides Sun, Proxima Centauri is the nearest star to the solar system. The Sun is the closest star to Earth, about 93 million miles away.

questions.Question: The time of Cairo is 2 hours ahead of Greenwich time Cairo is situated at ________
questions.solution: For every 1° longitude, there is a difference of 4 minutes For 2 hrs, there will be a difference of 30 degrees. So the correct answer is 30 degree east as Cairo is ahead of Greenwich time.

questions.Question: The speed of rotation of the earth is the highest ________
questions.solution: The earth rotates once every 23 hours, 56 minutes and 4.09053 seconds, called the sidereal period, and its circumference is roughly 40,075 kilometers. Thus, the surface of the earth at the equator moves at a speed of 460 meters per second - or roughly 1,000 miles per hour.

questions.Question: One degree of longitude on the equator is equal to a distance of ________
questions.solution: One degree of longitude on the equator is equal to a distance of 50 miles.

questions.Question: How much is the difference of time between any two consecutive longitudes?
questions.solution: 4 minutes is the difference of time between any two consecutive longitudes. The difference between the two longitudes that are adjacent is 4 minutes.

questions.Question: The approximate diameter of the earth is ________
questions.solution: The approximately diameter of Earth is 12800 km. The rotation of the planet has slightly flattened it out, so it has a larger diameter at the equator than at the poles. The equatorial diameter of Earth is 12,756 km, its polar diameter is 12,713 km, and its average diameter, which is referred to in common usage, is 12,742 km or 7,926 miles.

questions.Question: When the Moon completely covers the Sun, it is known as?
questions.solution: During a solar eclipse, the Moon actually casts two shadows toward Earth. One shadow is called the umbra which becomes smaller as it reaches the Earth. This is the dark center of the Moon's shadow.

questions.Question: Who Invented Universal Standard Time?
questions.solution: Sandford Fleming, a Canadian engineer invented the Universal Standard Time. Sir Sandford Fleming advocated the adoption of a standard time or mean time, as well as hourly variations from that according to established time zones.

questions.Question: How many time zones has the world been divided into?
questions.solution: There are 24 time zones in the world. This signifies that the Earth is divided into 24 'slices', and each time zone moves on one hour from the previous time zone and each 'slice', is 150 wide.

questions.Question: The point below the surface where an earthquake originates is called ________.
questions.solution: The focus is also called the hypocenter of an earthquake. The vibrating waves travel away from the focus of the earthquake in all directions.

questions.Question: The distance between two consecutive longitudes (91° E and 92° E) at the Poles is
questions.solution: The distance between two consecutive longitudes(91 degree E and 92 degree E) at the Poles is 0 km.

questions.Question: The place which has the longest day and the shortest night on 22nd December, is ________
questions.solution: The place which has the longest day and shortest night on 22 December is Melbourne.

questions.Question: Masses of stars and galaxies are usually expressed in ________.
questions.solution: Masses of stars and galaxies are usually expressed in Solar mass. The solar mass ( M ) is a standard unit of mass in astronomy, equal to approximately 2×1030 kg.

questions.Question: Tides in the sea have stored in them ________
questions.optionD: A combination of all the above three forms of energy
questions.solution: Tides in the sea have stored in them a combination of all the above three forms of energy.

questions.Question: Light from the Sun reaches us in nearly
questions.solution: The light from the sun takes about 8 minutes to reach the Earth after it has been emitted from the sun's surface.

questions.Question: The position of a planet when it is nearest to the Sun, is called ________
questions.solution: The closest point to the Sun in a planet's orbit is called perihelion. When Earth is at perihelion, it is about 147 million km (91 million miles) from the Sun.

questions.Question: How old is Earth, It is decided by which of the following processes?
questions.solution: The Earth is 4,54 billion years old. This age has been determined with the radioactive dating technique. The precise decay rate of radioactive elements is used as a clock: the number of daughter products in one rock indicates its age.

questions.Question: When it is 12:00 noon in India, the time in San Francisco (USA) would be closed to ________
questions.solution: When it is 12:00 noon in India, the time in San Francisco (USA) would be closed to 8 : 30 p. m. of previous day. India is 12 hours and 30 minutes ahead of San Francisco, CA, USA.

questions.Question: Which among the following imaginary line lies at 0° latitude?
questions.solution: Imaginary line lies at 0° latitude is Equator. Zero degrees latitude is the line designating the Equator and divides the Earth into two equal hemispheres (north and south).

questions.Question: Lunar eclipse occurs on ________
questions.solution: An eclipse of the Moon (or lunar eclipse) can only occur at Full Moon, and only if the Moon passes through some portion of Earth's shadow.

questions.Question: What can be the maximum duration of totality for a solar eclipse?
questions.solution: The maximum theoretical duration for a total solar eclipse is 7 min 40 sec.

questions.Question: If it is 4 P.M. on Monday at 150°W, what will be the time at 150°E ?
questions.solution: If it is 4 P.M. on Monday at 150°W, 12 Noon on Tuesday will be the time at 150°E.

questions.Question: The Tropic of Cancer does not pass through
questions.solution: In Asia, Tropic of Cancer passes through Myanmar, Oman, Bangladesh, India, Saudi Arabia, China, United Arab Emirates and Taiwan. Hence, The Tropic of cancer does not pass through Pakistan.

questions.Question: Which of these is the longest?
questions.solution: Latitude runs from 0° at the equator to 90°N or 90°S at the poles. Lines of latitude run in an east-west direction. Longitude runs from 0° at the prime meridian to 180° east or west, halfway around the globe. All are equal.

questions.Question: The Sun shines vertically on the equator ________
questions.solution: Equinox occurs when the sun is vertically above the equator. At this time, the sun equally illuminates the Southern and Northern hemisphere. At this time the world experiences equal day and night. Equinox occur twice a year. The months are March and September.

questions.Question: The difference in the duration of day and night increases as one moves from ________
questions.optionB: East and west of the prime meridian
questions.solution: As you move from the equator towards the poles, the latitude increases (up to 90 degrees). The further you go from the equator in any direction, the difference between the duration of the day and night in different times of the year will be bigger.

questions.Question: The longest circle which can be drawn on the earth's surface passes through ________
questions.solution: As you move from the equator towards the poles, the latitude increases (up to 90 degrees). The further you go from the equator in any direction, the difference between the duration of the day and night in different times of the year will be bigger.

questions.Question: The International Date Line passes through ________
questions.solution: It passes through the Bering Strait between the Diomede Islands at a distance of 1.5 kilometres (0.93 mi) from each island at 168°58′37″ W.

questions.Question: ________ is the time taken by the Earth to return to a given point in its orbit with reference to a fixed star.
questions.solution: Because, for all intents and purposes, the sky is "fixed", a sidereal day is when the earth rotates 360°. A sidereal day is 23 hours 56 minutes and 4.09 seconds long. A sidereal year is the time it takes for the sun to return to the same position with respect to the stars.

questions.Question: Through which one of the following countries the Tropic of Cancer does not pass through?
questions.solution: The Tropic of Cancer does not pass through Nepal.

questions.Question: One degree of the circumference of the earth measures(approx.) ________
questions.solution: One degree of the circumference of the earth measures(approx) 111 km.

questions.Question: The Earth rotates on its axis at an inclination of
questions.solution: Earth has seasons because our planet's axis of rotation is tilted at an angle of 23.5 degrees relative to our orbital plane – the plane of Earth's orbit around the sun.

questions.Question: If a solar eclipse occurs when the moon is quite far from the earth, the eclipse would likely to be ________
questions.solution: An annular solar eclipse (left) occurs when the Moon is too far away to completely cover the Sun's disk.

questions.Question: The earth rotates around its axis from ________
questions.solution: Earth rotates eastward, in prograde motion. As viewed from the north pole star Polaris, Earth turns counter clockwise. The North Pole, also known as the Geographic North Pole or Terrestrial North Pole, is the point in the Northern Hemisphere where Earth's axis of rotation meets its surface.

questions.Question: Days and nights are similar here
questions.solution: The Equator is exactly halfway in between the poles. So it wouldn't make any sense for a day on the equator to be longer when one of the poles is tilted towards the Sun, and shorter when the other one is. The days and nights remain equal here throughout the year.

questions.Question: Which of the following pairs is wrong?
questions.solution: An isohyet is a line on a map which connects points that have the same amounts of precipitation in a given period or for a particular storm. An isohyet is a form of map contour line displaying precipitation.

questions.Question: Latitude of place is indicative of its ________
questions.solution: Latitude affects temperature. One of the primary factors affecting the unequal heating of the Earth's atmosphere is latitude. Latitude is the measurement of the distance of a location on the Earth from the equator. The further away from the equator that a location resides, the less sunlight that this location receives.

questions.Question: Dolomite is a/an
questions.solution: Dolomite, also known as "dolostone" and "dolomite rock," is a sedimentary rock composed primarily of the mineral dolomite, CaMg(CO3)2. Dolomite is found in sedimentary basins worldwide. It is thought to form by the postdepositional alteration of lime mud and limestone by magnesium-rich groundwater.

questions.Question: What is the approximate circumference of Earth?
questions.solution: The circumference of the Earth in kilometers is 40,000 km(approx).

questions.Question: The Equator does not pass through which of the following?
questions.solution: The Equator does not pass through Mexico. The equator passes through 13 countries: Ecuador, Colombia, Brazil, Sao Tome & Principe, Gabon, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Uganda, Kenya, Somalia, Maldives, Indonesia and Kiribati.

questions.Question: The instrument to measure the area on maps is called
questions.solution: Planimeter also called platometer, it is an instrument used to measure an area of two dimensional shapes. eg. Area of maps.

questions.Question: What are the imaginary lines touching both the poles of Earth called?
questions.solution: Latitude is based on an imaginary line that circles Earth halfway between the north and south poles. Longitude refers to imaginary lines running vertically on the globe that bisect it through theNorth and the South Poles. Longitudes are angular distances measured from the Prime Meridian.

questions.Question: Who among the following was first to measure the circumference of the Earth?
questions.solution: Eratosthenes of Cyrene, 276 BC- 195 BC, was a Greek mathematician, geographer, poet, athlete, astronomer, and music theorist. He was the first person to use the word “geography” in Greek and he invented the discipline of geography as we understand it. He invented a system of latitude and longitude. He was the first person to calculate the circumference of the earth by using a measuring system using stades, or the length of stadiums during that time period (with remarkable accuracy).

questions.Question: What is the circumference of the Earth?
questions.solution: The approximate equatorial circumference of the earth is 40000 km.

questions.Question: Who was the first to measure the circumference of the Earth?
questions.solution: Eratosthenes was the first person to calculate the size of the earth. He was also the first person to use the word “Geography”.

questions.Question: The total surface area of earth is ________
questions.solution: The total surface area of the Earth is 510 million square km while that of India is 3.825 million square km.

questions.Question: The word "Isoneph" represents the lines of equal
questions.solution: The word "Isoneph" represents the lines of equal Cloudiness. An imaginary line connecting places which have similar amount of cloudiness for a given period of time is, Isoneph.

questions.Question: Which part of the earth's surface receives the highest amount of insolation?
questions.solution: Tropical deserts of the earth's surface receives the highest amount of insolation. Maximum insolation is received over the subtropical deserts, where the cloudiness is the least.

questions.Question: All the watches of a country are set according to ________
questions.solution: All the watches of a country are set according to standard time of the country. Because the same standard time for the whole country has been adopted, the watches show the same time in all parts of the country.

questions.Question: Maximum difference in the spacing of longitudes is ________
questions.solution: Maximum difference in the spacing of longitudes is at equator. At the equator, the distance between two latitudes and two longitudes is 111.1 kms.

questions.Question: Which one of the following minerals occurs abundantly in the Earth's crust?
questions.solution: Silica, also called silicon dioxide, compound of the two most abundant elements in Earth's crust, silicon and oxygen, SiO2. The mass of Earth's crust is 59 percent silica, the main constituent of more than 95 percent of the known rocks.

questions.Question: The latitude of a place expresses its angular position relative to the place of ________
questions.solution: The latitude of a place expresses its angular position relative to the place of Equator. The latitude of a place expresses its angular position relative to Equatorial Plane.

questions.Question: The Earth turns through 360° in 24 hours. Each 15° longitude represents ________
questions.solution: It takes 24 hours for the sun to go through the full 360 degrees around the world, so an hour of time is equal to 15 degrees of longitude.

questions.Question: The imaginary lines which connects the places of same temperature are called
questions.solution: The places which have similar temperature are connected by imaginary line known as Isotherm.

questions.Question: The imaginary line which connects places of similar height on map, are?
questions.solution: Contour lines are isolines joining places that have the same height value. Another common isoline is the isobar, a line that joins places with the same atmospheric pressure.

questions.Question: When does tides rise in sea?
questions.optionC: When Moon is on first phase
questions.solution: Tides rise in sea in Full Moon and half Moon. The moon and sun are primarily responsible for the rising and falling of ocean tides.

questions.Question: The speed of rotation of the earth is ________
questions.solution: The speed of rotation of the earth is 9.72 km/sec.

questions.Question: The distance of the equator from either of the poles is ________
questions.solution: The distance of the equator from either of the poles is 10,002 km.

questions.Question: The Earth rotates-around an axis pointing towards ________
questions.solution: The Earth rotates-around an axis pointing towards the Pole star. The axis of rotation of the Earth passes very close to the Pole Star. The earth rotates around the sun, but the polar star is always in the north.

questions.Question: When a ship crosses Date line from west to east ________
questions.solution: When a ship crosses the International Date Line from west to east, it adds a day, and if it crosses the line from east to west, it subtracts a day.

questions.Question: The network of the series of vertical and horizontal lines is known as
questions.solution: The network of the series of vertical and horizontal lines is known as Geographical Coordinates System. There are 2 co-ordinate values for a point latitude and longitude. A geographic coordinate system (GCS) uses a three-dimensional spherical surface to define locations on the earth. A GCS is often incorrectly called a datum, but a datum is only one part of a GCS. A GCS includes an angular unit of measure, a prime meridian, and a datum (based on a spheroid).

questions.Question: At the summer solstice, which one of the following latitudes will have the longest night?
questions.solution: At the summer solstice, which one of the following latitudes will have the longest night 60°S. The summer solstice, also known as midsummer, occurs when one of the Earth's poles has its maximum tilt toward the Sun.

questions.Question: The most abundant metal in the Earth's Crust is
questions.solution: Aluminum is the third most abundant element in Earth's crust. Aluminum does not exist as a lone element, and it is found as a compound. Abundant compounds of Aluminum include aluminum oxide, aluminum hydroxide, and potassium aluminum sulfate.

questions.Question: Which of the followings are related with "Lithosphere"?
questions.solution: The word lithosphere is made up of two words i.e. litho and sphere. 'Litho', means crust (rock) solid. Thus the term 'Lithosphere' signifies Earth crust. Earth's lithosphere includes the crust and the uppermost mantle, which constitute the hard and rigid outer layer of the Earth.

questions.Question: The surface of Earth that lies between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn is called ________
questions.solution: The torrid zone refers to the area of the earth between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn.

questions.Question: In which of the following areas, the "Midnight Sun" can be seen?
questions.solution: Midnight Sun is a name given the sun when it can be seen at midnight during the Arctic or Antarctic summer. This phenomenon occurs in summer months in places north of Arctic or south of Antarctic circle when Sun is visible in this region during mid night hours also.

questions.Question:
Which of the following countries are located on the Greenwich Meridian?
1. Algeria
2. Germany
3. Guinea
4. Iceland
questions.solution: Germany is located on the Greenwich Meridian. Germany is bordered to the north by the North Sea, Denmark , and the Baltic Sea, to the south by Austria and Switzerland , to the west by France , Belgium , The Netherlands and Luxembourg and to the east by Poland and the Czech Republic.

questions.Question: What is the approximate equatorial circumference of the earth?
questions.solution: The approximate equatorial circumference of the earth is 40000 km.

questions.Question: The earth is at the least distance from the sun (Perihelion) on ________
questions.solution: On January 3, Earth reaches perihelion, its closest point to the Sun in its yearly orbit around our star.

questions.Question: The Mohorovicic (Moho) Discontinuity separates
questions.solution: Mohorovicic Discontinuity lies between Crust & Mantle, the word 'discontinuity' used here represents the (region) where seismic waves change velocity.

questions.Question: The antipodal position of a place located at 35° south and 80° west is
questions.solution: The antipodal position of a place located at 35° south and 80° west is 35° north and 100° East.

questions.Question: The International Dateline deflects to a side to avoid ________
questions.solution: International Date Line follows the meridian of 180° longitude down the middle of the Pacific Ocean for some time. In the north the date line turns to the east through the Bering Strait and then west past the Aleutian Islands in order to keep Alaska and Russia on opposite sides of the line.

questions.Question: Tides are caused by the gravitational forces of
questions.optionC: Of Sun and Moon on Earth
questions.solution: Gravity is one major force that creates tides. In 1687, Sir Isaac Newton explained that ocean tides result from the gravitational attraction of the sun and moon on the oceans of the earth.

questions.Question: What is the alternate name for contour lines?
questions.solution: Isohypse is an imaginary line connecting points (places) at equal heights & equal barometric pressures which is similar to contours which connects places of equal height.

questions.Question: 1-degree of latitude is equal to
questions.solution: At the equator, the length of 1o of latitude is equal to 110.6 km (68.7 mi.) and at the poles, the length of 1o of latitude is equal to 111.7 km (69.4 mi.). For our purposes, we assume the length of one degree of latitude is 111 km. Lines of longitude, also called meridians, run north - south.

questions.Question: Equinox occurs when the Sun is vertically above
questions.solution: It is the moment at which the center of the visible Sun is directly above the Equator. In the northern hemisphere, the equinox in March is called the Vernal or Spring Equinox; the September equinox is called the Autumnal or Fall Equinox.

questions.Question: How many Geo-synchronous satellites are required for uninterrupted world broadcasting?
questions.solution: In theory, 2 satellites in diametrically opposite geo-synchronous orbits could cover the planet. In order for the satellites to communicate, a minimum of 3 would be needed, each at a 60 degree angle to the others. At this point, the strength and quality of coverage increases proportionally to the number of satellites.

questions.Question: What is known as High Pressure Subtropical Latitude?
questions.solution: The horse latitudes are subtropical regions known for calm winds and little precipitation. The horse latitudes are regions located at about 30 degrees north and south of the equator. These latitudes are characterized by calm winds and little precipitation.

questions.Question: The Synchronous satellite moves around the Earth from
questions.solution: Synchronous satellite is an artificial satellite moving in circular orbit round the Earth in 24 hours duration along with the rotatory movement of Earth i.e. west to east.

questions.Question: What is the name of the maps, natural and manmade, portray the large forms?
questions.solution: They emphasize on a particular theme or topic such as average rain, climatic condition, pressure in particular months etc. These are diffirent from general maps.

questions.Question: The latitude of a place expresses its angular position relative to the plane of
questions.solution: The latitude of a place expresses its angular position relative to the plane of equator.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not the effect of the revolution of the Earth.
questions.optionD: Change in the direction of winds and ocean currents
questions.solution: Our planet's rotation produces a force on all bodies moving relative to the Earth. Due to Earth's approximately spherical shape, this force is greatest at the poles and least at the Equator. The force, called the "Coriolis effect," causes the direction of winds and ocean currents to be deflected.
